name: Apollo 11
objective: The historic mission that landed the first humans on the Moon. Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin walked on the lunar surface while Michael Collins orbited above.
details: Apollo 11 was the culmination of the Space Race and fulfilled President Kennedy's goal of landing a man on the Moon before 1970. The mission lasted 8 days and returned with 47.5 pounds of lunar samples.

name: Voyager 1
objective: An interstellar probe that has traveled farther from Earth than any other spacecraft. It carries a golden record with sounds and images from Earth.
details: Voyager 1 has entered interstellar space and continues to send data back to Earth. The Golden Record contains 115 images, natural sounds, musical selections, and greetings in 55 languages.

name: Artemis I
objective: The first integrated test of NASA's deep space exploration systems: the Orion spacecraft, Space Launch System rocket, and ground systems.
details: Artemis I was an uncrewed mission that paved the way for future crewed missions to the Moon. It tested the Orion spacecraft in a lunar environment and demonstrated its ability to return safely to Earth.

name: Hubble Space Telescope
objective: One of the most successful scientific instruments ever built. It has provided breathtaking images and revolutionary discoveries about the universe.
details: Hubble orbits Earth at an altitude of about 547 kilometers and has made over 1.5 million observations. It has helped determine the age of the universe and discovered dark energy.

name: Spirit Rover
objective: A Mars rover that operated for 15 years, far exceeding its planned 90-day mission. It discovered evidence that water once flowed on Mars.
details: Spirit explored the Gusev Crater and climbed the Columbia Hills. It discovered evidence of ancient hot springs and volcanic activity, providing crucial insights into Mars' wet past.

name: Curiosity Rover
objective: A car-sized rover exploring Gale Crater on Mars. It has determined that Mars once had conditions favorable for microbial life.
details: Curiosity is equipped with 17 cameras and a suite of scientific instruments. It has found organic molecules and seasonal variations in methane, suggesting potential biological activity.

name: Rosetta
objective: The first spacecraft to orbit a comet and deploy a lander on its surface. It studied comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko for over two years.
details: Rosetta's Philae lander was the first to make a controlled touchdown on a comet nucleus. The mission provided unprecedented data about comets' composition and behavior.

name: Cassini-Huygens
objective: A mission to Saturn that revolutionized our understanding of the ringed planet and its moons, particularly Titan and Enceladus.
details: Cassini orbited Saturn for 13 years, discovering water-ice geysers on Enceladus and liquid methane seas on Titan. The Huygens probe successfully landed on Titan in 2005.

name: James Webb Space Telescope
objective: The most powerful space telescope ever built. It observes the universe in infrared light to see the first galaxies and study exoplanets.
details: JWST is located at the L2 Lagrange point, 1.5 million km from Earth. Its 6.5-meter primary mirror and infrared capabilities allow it to see through dust clouds and observe the earliest galaxies.

name: New Horizons
objective: First mission to Pluto and the Kuiper Belt. It provided the first close-up images of Pluto and continues to explore the outer solar system.
details: New Horizons completed its historic flyby of Pluto in 2015, revealing a geologically active world with mountains and plains. It then visited Kuiper Belt object Arrokoth in 2019.
